skill.name: vaex
skill.description: Use this skill for processing and analyzing large tabular datasets (billions of rows) that exceed available RAM. Vaex excels at out-of-core DataFrame operations, lazy evaluation, fast aggregations, efficient visualization of big data, and machine learning on large datasets. Apply when users need to work with large CSV/HDF5/Arrow/Parquet files, perform fast statistics on massive datasets, create visualizations of big data, or build ML pipelines that do not fit in memory.
skill.summary: Use this skill for processing and analyzing large tabular datasets (billions of rows) that exceed av...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate Vaex documentation skill containing only markdown reference files. All 492 static findings are false positives triggered by markdown code formatting (backticks misinterpreted as Ruby/shell commands), documentation text about algorithms, and legitimate library features like memory-mapping. No actual executable code, credential handling, or malicious patterns exist.

content.value_statement: Work with datasets too large for standard tools. Vaex processes billions of rows using memory-efficient out-of-core DataFrames with lazy evaluation. Apply fast aggregations, visualizations, and ML on data that exceeds available RAM.
actual_capabilities: Load and process datasets larger than available RAM using memory-mapping
Perform fast statistical aggregations on billion-row datasets
Create interactive visualizations of large-scale data with heatmaps and scatter plots
Build ML pipelines with transformers, encoders, and model integration
Read and write data in HDF5, Parquet, Arrow, CSV, and cloud storage formats
limitations: Focused on tabular data - not suitable for unstructured data or graph data
Requires data to be in supported formats (HDF5, Parquet, Arrow, CSV, FITS)
Limited to single-machine processing - not distributed computing

use_cases.title: Analyze massive datasets
use_cases.description: Explore billion-row datasets interactively without loading everything into memory.

use_cases.title: Process large-scale data
use_cases.description: Handle astronomical, genomic, or financial time series data too large for pandas.

use_cases.title: Build big data pipelines
use_cases.description: Create feature engineering and ML workflows that scale beyond RAM limitations.

prompt_templates.title: Load large dataset
prompt_templates.prompt: Use Vaex to open my large HDF5/Parquet file and show me the first few rows, column types, and basic statistics.

prompt_templates.title: Filter and aggregate
prompt_templates.prompt: Filter my dataset using Vaex expressions and compute mean, sum, and count grouped by a categorical column.

prompt_templates.title: Create visualization
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a heatmap or scatter plot of my large dataset using Vaex visualization with proper axis limits.

prompt_templates.title: Build ML pipeline
prompt_templates.prompt: Use Vaex ML to create a feature engineering pipeline with scaling and encoding, then integrate with scikit-learn for model training.

output_examples.input: Load my 10GB CSV file and show me the distribution of the 'value' column
output: Dataset loaded successfully: 10.5 GB, 150 million rows, 25 columns
Column 'value' statistics: min=0.1, max=9876.5, mean=156.3, std=45.2
Created histogram showing value distribution with 100 bins
Virtual column 'value_normalized' added for future use

best_practices: Use HDF5 or Apache Arrow formats for optimal performance with repeated access
Create virtual columns instead of materializing data to save memory
Enable lazy evaluation with delay=True when performing multiple operations
anti_patterns: Converting Vaex DataFrames to pandas for operations that Vaex can handle directly
Using CSV format for datasets accessed repeatedly - convert to HDF5 or Arrow
Materializing intermediate results when virtual columns would suffice

faq.question: How does Vaex handle datasets larger than RAM?
faq.answer: Vaex uses memory-mapping to access files on disk without loading them entirely. Operations are lazy and only compute when needed.

faq.question: What file formats does Vaex support?
faq.answer: HDF5, Apache Arrow, Parquet, CSV, FITS, and can convert from pandas DataFrames and NumPy arrays.

faq.question: Can Vaex integrate with scikit-learn?
faq.answer: Yes, Vaex ML provides transformers that create virtual columns. State can be saved and loaded for production deployments.

faq.question: How fast is Vaex for large datasets?
faq.answer: Vaex can process over one billion rows per second on standard hardware for many aggregation operations.

faq.question: Does Vaex support cloud storage?
faq.answer: Yes, Vaex can read from and write to S3, Google Cloud Storage, and Azure Blob Storage using appropriate filesystem libraries.

faq.question: What is lazy evaluation in Vaex?
faq.answer: Operations are not executed immediately but stored as expressions. They only compute when the result is needed, enabling efficient batching.
